description.narrative:
The Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC) har ansökt om kärnstöd till Sida om ett totalt belopp om 30 miljoner kronor för juli 2021 - december 2023 som stöd i genomförandet av organisationens strategiska plan "Building Peace Together: Globalising Local Voices, Localising Global Commitments" 2021-2025.
GPPAC är ett globalt nätverk av civilsamhällesorganisationer som aktivt verkar för att förhindra våldsam konflikt och bygga mer fredliga samhällen. Nätverket består av 15 regionala nätverk, var och ett med sina egna prioriteringar, karaktär och agenda - utifrån den regionala kontexten och behov. GPPAC har för närvarande cirka 240 medlemmar, vilket gör organisationen till världens största globala nätverk av lokala fredsbyggare. GPPAC:s övergripande mål för dess strategiska plan "Building Peace Together: Globalising Local Voices, Localising Global Commitments" 2021-2025 är att policy, praktik och infrastruktur ska vara förankrade i lokalt drivet och lokalt grundat fredsbyggande med fokus på tre tematiska områden: 1. Lokalt ledd fredsbyggande verksamhet 2. Inkluderande av fredsbyggare som är kvinnor och unga 3. Klimatsäkerhet och begynnande hot
GPPAC's totala budget för den period för vilken den har sökt stöd från Sida för är ungefär 38 miljoner kronor. Sida är för närvarande den huvudsakliga finansiären av GPPAC. Sida planerar att även stödja GPPAC med en extern översyn av organisationens interna styrning och kontroll under hösten 2021, liksom med medel till en halvtidsöversyn av genomförandet av den strategiska planen 2023.

The Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC) has applied to Sida for core support amounting to 30 million SEK for July 2021 - December 2023 in support of the organisation's Strategic Plan "Building Peace Together: Globalising Local Voices, Localising Global Commitments" 2021-2025.
GPPAC is a global network of civil society organisations (CSOs) actively working to prevent violent conflict and build more peaceful societies. The network consists of 15 regional networks, each with its own priorities, character, and agenda – tailored to the regional context and needs. GPPAC currently has around 240 members, which makes the organisation the world’s largest global network of local peacebuilders. GPPAC's overarching aim for its strategic plan is for policies, practices and infrastructures to be rooted in locally-led and locally-grounded peacebuilding with a focus on three thematic areas: 1. Locally-led Peacebuilding Action 2. Inclusion of Women and Youth Peacebuilders 3. Climate Security and Emerging Threats
GPPAC's total budget for the period it has requested support from Sida is approximately 38 million SEK. Sida is currently the main funder to GPPAC. Sida is planning to also support GPPAC with an external review of the organisation's internal management and control during the fall of 2021, as well as funds for a mid-term review of the implementation of the Strategic Plan in 2023.

The overarching aim for the Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC), a global network of civil society organisations (CSOs), and its strategic plan "Building Peace Together: Globalising Local Voices, Localising Global Commitments" 2021-2025 is for policies, practices and infrastructures to be rooted in locally-led and locally-grounded peacebuilding with a focus on three thematic areas: 1. Locally-led Peacebuilding Action - with a focus on both building and sustaining inclusive infrastructures for peace centred around local ownership, and facilitating multi-stakeholder engagements that explore and promote innovative ways of increasing accessible funding for local peacebuilders. 2. Inclusion of Women and Youth Peacebuilders - strengthening the capacity of the GPPAC network for inclusive peacebuilding and conflict prevention; by supporting the network's gender and youth experts in strategically engaging in peacebuilding processes at every level; and by ensuring that members contribute to further develop and implement global policies and frameworks. 3. Climate Security and Emerging Threats - by capitalising on the expertise and experience of GPPAC members. Through cross-regional learning, GPPAC aims to build the knowledge and understanding of GPPAC members to mainstream a peacebuilding response to climate-related risks and other emerging threats in programming, and influence power holders to do the same. To achieve this, GPPAC foresees working through what it describes as three Pathways of Change. Firstly, to amplify member expertise by strengthening the network's platforms for exchange of expertise and learning and to facilitate organisational development within regional networks. Secondly, to mobilise collective action by enhancing collaboration and joint action between members at all levels. And thirdly, to influence policy and practice by building capacity and create space for meaningful engagement of local peacebuilders at the regional and international levels to raise visibility of and gain support for local peacebuilding work.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

description.narrative: No results reported yet as the agreement spans from 1 July 2021. See the Sida support to GPPAC 2017-2021 for previous results.
